title: Tuesday, 12th January, 2016

11:10 am
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 77.55, up 11.55 (+17.50%), High: 77.90, Low: 72.60, Volume: 4.73m
PM

As in burning of the shorts

BE

Basically, Christmas wasn't entirely awful so it's corrected back to its level at the start of December.

11:12 am
BE

Sports Direct's warning on Friday looked bad for Debenhams, of course, given Sports Direct's hermited into a fair amount of Debs' floorspace.

BE

But then, Debs investors might've missed that Sports Direct's profit warning wasn't actually a profit warning. As we've said ad nauseum.

PM

hehe

11:13 am
PM

Good point

BE

Anyway, does this mean Debenhams is suddenly a decent business rather than a five floor jumble sale?

PM

Please say no

11:13 am
BE

Of course not. But it deserves a slightly higher rating than it did yesterday. Here's Deutsche.

BE

Like for likes at constant currency rose by +3.5%, around 200bps better than expected. Debenhams executed its peak trading plans very well. Outerwear inventory levels were reduced by 23% and options were correspondingly reduced. Availability improved, in contrast to peers, helped by extending its ‘endless aisle’ to 140 stores. The emphasis on non-apparel was a benefit, and we estimate (Figure 3) that all of the growth came from these categories. At the same time, full price sales grew more quickly than discount sales in both apparel and non-apparel. We estimate (Figure 2) that UK store LFLs grew by +1%. Although this is still modest, this is the first growth since 2012.

BE

Forecasts edge up 0.5%: positive news given the valuation
We still have reservations about Debenhams’ ability to grow profits sustainably. However, our forecasts for FY Aug-16 (PBT £118m) appear well-underpinned, given that H1 is around 80% of annual profits (DBe £92m). We estimate gross margins in the 19 week period were flat (FY guidance 0 to 50bps) as non-apparel’s lower margin mix offset the reduced discounting. We estimate operating cost growth to be c.+3% for the full year, in the mid-point of full year guidance of 2% to 4%.

11:14 am
BE

Target price maintained at 85p
Our target price continues to be based on DCF (WACC 8.5%, RFR 4.5%, ERP 4.5%, beta 1.1, all assumptions in line with those used for other stocks in the sector), and terminal growth of -1% to reflect Debenhams' maturity profile. In our view, upside risks include success of a number of current initiatives which are designed to boost profitable sales. Downside risks relate to the need to continue investing, both opex and capex, or increased competitive intensity in the mid-market led by an M&S revival.

PM

Shore brave enough to cut their target price this morning

PM

We remain concerned on the longer term prospects of the company. However, there is no doubt, in our view, that the stock has been recently oversold. This update is better than our and market expectations so we would expect some recovery in the share price. We reiterate our HOLD recommendation but reduce our TP to 75p from 85p.

11:15 am
PM

Freddie George

PM

NOT SHORE

PM

Sorry

11:15 am
PM

Cantor

BE

RBC, meanwhile, talking about Debs being a bid target again.

BE

Further consolidation potential in department store sector: Following Sainsbury's approach for Home Retail announced last week we think investors are
likely to look for other consolidation candidates in the sector. Structural pressures on department stores have led to a wave of consolidation in the sector over
the past five years and we think this may continue in 2016. We discuss this more in our year ahead report (theme number 8). Outlook 2016: European General
Retail - Staying online in 2016
Press reports in the past e.g. Citywire 2015 have highlighted the strategic value of Debenhams. It remains a cash generative business (12% FCF yield), and its
CEO Michael Sharp is due to leave the company later in 2016. Debenhams has a strong market position in Beauty and parts of clothing, a broad range and
almost 100% brand recognition in the UK with now over 20% of sales and profit from international operations e.g. Denmark.

11:16 am
BE

Our view: Outperform. We think the Debenhams share price is now pricing in a moderate decline in FCF per year, but we expect this to be resilient and
recent LFL trends have been better than expected. Also we see a strong chance of further consolidation newsflow in the department store sector following
recent consolidation in Ireland and Germany. Debenhams trades at c.9x cal. 16 P/E, a c.40% discount to the sector compared to 25-30% historically and offers
a c.12% FCF yield and +5% dividend yield.

BE

But who'd buy Debs? It's already been gutted by PE. Twice, in fact.

BE

And Sports Direct's only interested in Debs as a way to get Adidas and Nike onside

11:17 am
BE

Whose sales folk, for whatever reason, see department stores as better than stack-em-high discounters that draw you in on the promise of Nike then sell you Lonsdale.

BE

It's interesting, incidentally, how low-key the Sports Direct branding is on their Debs concessions. Stealth, even.

BE

But that's Debs. And let's move on.

11:27 am
BE

Alternatively, to clear some of this dead air, here's SocGen.

BE

Main surprises This time round we have a positive surprise. The Christmas trading
statement (nine weeks to 3 January) shows LFL sales growth ex fuel at 0.2%, materially
better than consensus on -2%. This encouraging performance was driven by aggressive
pricing investment (internal deflation ex fuel of 3.2% vs 2.2% deflation over the previous
quarter), a more efficient pricing policy (bigger promotions, strong focus on ‘Every Day low
Prices’) and refresh of the assortment. Guidance: the group is guiding to FY 15-16 PBT in
a £295-310m range (SGe £291m). We highlight implicitly good control of FCF as the group
has set a new year-end net debt target of £1.65-1.8bn (was ‘below £1.9bn’).

BE

Potential impact on SG & market forecast We see scope for consensus to rise by some
7-8% to approach the high end of £295-310m PBT guidance for 2015-16.

11:27 am
BE

Potential impact on share price/recommendation This performance is encouraging and
we expect a positive share price reaction today. Our TP is based on a peer comparison
(160p at a 15% discount to the European sector average 2015-16e EV/sales ratio) and a
DCF (140p, 8.4% WACC, 1.5% growth to perpetuity, 3.4% norm. EBIT margin as of 2022-
23e). Risks to recommendation, rating and target price: Morrisons demonstrates
unexpectedly strong ability to improve its market share trends (-20bp for 12 weeks to 6
Dec) and protect its LFL sales growth (all else being equal, 1% of additional LFL sales
leads to 20bp EBIT margin improvement); Successful development of e-commerce
business (below 2% of sales in 2015-16 on our estimates); Further deterioration in the
competitive environment (Morrisons plans to invest further £700m in 2015-16 and 2016-17).

BE

And now Bubb, Neil?

NC

Grocery Market Share Watch: The latest monthly Kantar Grocery market share data has just been released, for the 12 weeks ending 3 January 2016 and the main conclusion is that there was ”no Christmas uplift for the British grocery market, as sales fell by 0.2% on last year thanks to continuing price deflation. However the discount retailers, Waitrose, the Co-op and Sainsbury’s (+0.8%) successfully grew ahead of the market and were the market share winners over Christmas”.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 155.50, up 10.05 (+6.91%), High: 155.50, Low: 151.70, Volume: 14.36m

11:29 am
BE

Good question, which I'll come to.

BE

First, though, Barclays re Tesco.

BE

Kantar has just released market share data for the 4 weeks to 3 January 2016. The most significant message is that Tesco appears to have done far better than might have been feared when the market was looking at the data in the autumn and anticipating the much tougher Christmas comps from 2014. Its sales declined by only -1.0%, in the context of -3.4% in the prior period and a comparative that got c4ppts tougher. So against a ‘mechanical expectation’ of a -7.3% decline, Tesco’s -1.0% fall was far less severe. The others were less surprising – Sainsbury is the ‘winner’ among the big players in the sense of having seen the smallest decline, but its margin of victory is perhaps slimmer than expected. The data suggests that Morrison’s sales growth was driven strongly by alcoholic drinks – as the company itself called out in this morning’s trading statement. Looking at the wider industry trends, deflation eased very slightly (from -1.9% to -1.8%) and the discounters remained strong (accelerating on a four-week average, slowing on a 12-week average).

11:30 am
BE

Today we have seen Morrison’s Christmas trading statement, tomorrow we have Sainsbury and Thursday we have Tesco. We published our previews last week, suggesting that Sainsbury will publish a LFL decline of c-0.5% for the 15 weeks to 9 January and that Tesco will report a LFL decline of c-2.0% for the six weeks to 9 January. This set of data suggests that Tesco may be able to report a slightly better number than we forecast, although the time periods are not aligned perfectly and the market share data is not directly comparable to LFL data given store closures and definitional differences. For Sainsbury, the market share data seems broadly supportive of our forecast.

BE

Review of the market share data
From an industry perspective, growth was flat in the four-week period ending 3 January, slightly up from the -0.2% last time. On a 12-week rolling average industry growth decelerated slightly, from 0.4% last time to 0.1%.
Kantar Worldpanel mentions that grocery deflation was -1.8% in the 12-week period ending 3 January, marginally up from the -1.9% in the previous period. The deflation still reflects the ongoing price competition between major supermarkets and hard discounters, as well as falling prices in some major categories such as eggs, butter and crisps, according to Kantar Worldpanel.

11:45 am
BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Group LfL order growth of 46% for the FY implies Q4 of c.43%. It implies
a slowdown from the 47-48% that has been reported Q1-Q3 and it is the first
quarter where order growth is below 47% since IPO. The company points out
that at an absolute level, order growth was greater in Q4 compared to Q3,
although that would be expected as Q3 is a seasonally weaker quarter given
the better weather and holiday season. We think the 43% is at the lower end of
investor expectations. The company does not provide the geographic
breakdown, but it says that trends in the UK relative to the group reflect
previous quarters, which we take to mean Q4 order growth of 44-45%.

BE

Despite the lower than expected LfL order number, the company says it
is in an "excellent position for the full year results". The company had
previously guided to revenue of £240m and EBITDA of c.£55m based on Q4
order growth of c.40%. The additional 3%-points in the quarter might take it to
£245m. We currently forecast revenue of £241m and EBITDA of £57m. We are
broadly in-line with consensus revenue of £242m and EBITDA of £57m.

11:46 am
BE

The company will be reporting FY results on 1st March. We expect the
company to provide revenue guidance for 2016. We forecast £319m of
revenue and £85m of EBITDA. Consensus forecasts £321m of revenue and
£89m of EBITDA. Whilst it would imply a deceleration in LfL order growth to
30%, we think this is reasonable as it would imply similar growth on an
absolute £ basis. On our numbers, the shares are trading on 36x EV/EBITDA
and we are Equal-weight the shares with a 450p price target.

BE

36x EV/EBITDA for a slowing business. Okay. Suit yourself.

an "excellent position for the full year results".

11:52 am
BE

We remain confident in JE’s ability to grow its user base over the medium term.
According to the company, seven in ten consumers in the UK, arguably JE’s most
developed market, still order takeaway for delivery offline, but we believe the attraction
of online takeaway will continue to drive channel shift. We expect continued top-line
growth, with profits growing well in excess of revenues as fixed costs and marketing
expenditure are leveraged – the UK segment reported a 44.5% EBITDA margin in H1,
while margins for the business as a whole were 23.9%. The group is generating strong
cash conversion (FY15E: 88%), adding to a cash holding which we estimate at £188m
as of FY15. In our view, while the likelihood of large M&A is diminishing, JE still has
significant potential in its existing markets, particularly in early-stage markets such
as Brazil and Mexico. And in its more developed markets, we believe the likelihood for
commission rate increases is rising, which could have a material impact on our forecasts.

BE

We upgrade our FY15E/FY16E revenue expectations by 1.2%/1.3%, and our EBITDA
rises 3.4%3.4% to £57.2m£91.9m respectively. See page 3 for more detail.
Recommendation & valuation
JE shares have risen 45% on a 12-month view, supported by rapid earnings growth.
The shares currently trade on 50x calendar 2016E PER and 32x EV/EBITDA. We are
increasing our DCF-derived target price by 3.5%, in line with our EBITDA upgrade, to
595p (previously 575p). At this price, the shares trade on 62.2x 2016E PER and 40.7x
EV/EBITDA, falling to 45.9x and 29.8x in 2017E, respectively. We believe JE deserves
a premium rating relative to peers, given our forecasts for high earnings growth, strong
profit margins and good free cash flow generation.

BE

And that's enough JE.

Cineworld requested.

Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 518.50, down 19 (-3.53%), High: 532.50, Low: 502.50, Volume: 577.72k
BE

Results okay. But it was hardly a secret that Star Wars was coming out.

11:57 am
BE

Singer downgrades. Valuation.

BE

Cineworld has released an in line YE trading update, with double-digit growth across the 3 revenue drivers. We were

anticipating a forecast beat, so are a tad disappointed from this perspective. New openings for FY15 are broadly in line

but we note the FY16 guidance looks light relative to previous guidance. Our Buy stance has served us well for the last 18

months, but we expect the shares to consolidate at current levels over the first half of 2016 and thus move to a Hold with

a 550p TP.

BE

Total revenue growth is reported at 12.3% CC (9.1% post FX hit), split 11.6% UK (vs our 14%) and 13.7% CEE. Cineworld was always going to be a H2 story this year and so it proved to be the case with H2 numbers robust. Accordingly Box office revenue was 11.6% higher y-o-y (11.2% UK / 12.7% CEE). This helped drive 13.7% higher Retail revenue and a 13.4% uplift in Other revenue.

Fundamentally Cineworld is a roll out story and to this end 18 new sites were added in the period, 1 short of our forecast. We note the number of Satrbucks outlets increased to 17 in the year. The new opening guidance for FY16 is 13, which is broadly in line with our conservatively pitched assumption but 5 less than the broad steer given at the Augsut’15 interims.There is still no news on the vacant FD position.

Impact on earnings & valuation

Management is guiding to a full year ‘in line with current market expectations’. Our £153.5m EBITDA for FY15 remains unchanged and is broadly in line with consensus, albeit at the EPS level we are 2% ahead. Looking forward we are projecting 9% EPS growth on the back of roll-out and a solid (rather than spectacular) film line up. Our Buy stance over 2015 served us very well but we envisage the shares consolidating at current levels over H1-16, with interest in the story reviving later in the year as investors switch attention to the prospects of a bumper outlook for FY17. We fundamentally like the mid-term emerging market story at Cineworld but for now move back to a Hold with a 550p TP.

Sky News has learnt that Melrose is contemplating whether to join an auction of the business, which is drawing interest from some of the world's largest buyout funds.

If Melrose secures a deal to buy the Philips division, it would mark the British company's largest takeover to date, but would also represent a departure from the series of acquisitions it has made since it launched 13 years ago.

n up and coming lifestyle architecture group is ringing in 2016 with the launch of a motivation and strategy retreat designed to help entrepreneurs tap into ten strike success. Scheduled for Feb 26-28, Flow Club by City Calm will provide practical, actionable workshops in mindfulness, mindset and business strategy. The three day weekend is designed to leave entrepreneurs feeling empowered and buzzing with ideas they can develop for long term business success.

The February Flow Club by City Calm retreat will launch in the wake of the unprecedented success of the first online course and offline workshops. Together with Portuguese-based mindful living group SensaVida, City Calm has developed an intensive three day programme that hands attendees the power to break through limiting beliefs that could be holding them back. The retreat will be held in the Portuguese city of Tomar, a tranquil municipality where attendees can step out of their comfort zone and tap into their inner power.
